studyAmendmentImpacts.affectedSection: Synopsis; 3.1 Overview of Study Design; 10.1 Completion; 11.2 Sample Size Determination; 11.3 Efficacy Analysis; 17.9.1 Final OS Analysis/End of study
studyAmendmentImpacts.description: Defined clinical cut-off for final CSR analysis, transition to long-term survival follow-up, and final OS analysis timing.
Clarified permitted and prohibited vaccinations, specifically restricting live-attenuated vaccines.

studyAmendmentImpacts.affectedSection: Synopsis; 3.1 Overview of Study Design; 6 Dosage and Administration
studyAmendmentImpacts.description: Introduced the option for subjects to switch from daratumumab IV to daratumumab subcutaneous (SC) administration.

studyAmendmentImpacts.affectedSection: 8.1.7 Management of Hepatitis B Virus Reactivation; 9.8 Safety Evaluations
studyAmendmentImpacts.description: Added monitoring and management protocols for Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) reactivation risk.

studyAmendmentReasons.reasonText: To define the clinical cut-off for the final CSR analysis and revise the end of study definition.
To provide flexibility for study investigators to prioritize patient safety during the global COVID-19 pandemic.
In response to identification of a new important risk (hepatitis B virus [HBV] reactivation).
Following IDMC review, allow Arm A subjects access to daratumumab after confirmed disease progression.

studyChanges.afterText: End of study defined as when all subjects still receiving daratumumab have access through another source, or all discontinued, or by 31 January 2026.
studyChanges.summary: Defined the specific end of study date and conditions.

studyChanges.afterText: Restriction of live-attenuated and replication-competent viral vector vaccines.
studyChanges.summary: Added specific prohibitions for certain vaccine types.

studyChanges.afterText: Daratumumab SC 1800 mg administration via subcutaneous injection.
studyChanges.summary: Added subcutaneous route of administration for daratumumab.

studyChanges.beforeText: Doses delayed for more than 4 weeks (Cycle 1 to 6) or 6 weeks (Cycle 7+) should be discontinued.
studyChanges.afterText: Doses delayed for more than 4 weeks (Cycle 1 to 6) or 6 weeks (Cycle 7+) should be discontinued, unless agreed upon with sponsor.
studyChanges.summary: Added flexibility for treatment continuation after prolonged delay upon sponsor consultation.

studyChanges.beforeText: Samples are requested at time of suspected CR/sCR and at 12, 18, 24, and 30 months.
studyChanges.afterText: Samples are requested at time of suspected CR/sCR and at 12, 18, 24, 30, 36, 48, and 60 months.
studyChanges.summary: Extended the duration of MRD monitoring timepoints.
